clinical_study.brief_title: Nonsurgical or Surgical Treatment of ACL Injuries
clinical_study.official_title: Dynamic Stability of the ACL Deficient Knee

oversight_info.authority: Norway: The National Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to evaluate knee function, sports participation and knee reinjuries over 2 years in a group of patients who choose either nonsurgical or surgical treatment for an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury

detailed_description.textblock: This study is a part study of an overall study with the title 'Dynamic stability of the ACL-injured knee'. The overall study prospectively follows a cohort of newly injured patients with total rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament in the knee.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

secondary_outcome.measure: Isokinetic knee extensor and flexor muscle strength
Participation in level I, II and III sports

arm_group.description: Patients who undergo rehabilitation and anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, other surgical interventions may be performed
Patients who undergo rehabilitation without anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, other surgical interventions may be performed

study_pop.textblock: Athletically active anterior cruciate ligament injured patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Anterior cruciate ligament rupture within 3 months of injury
- Preinjury participation in level I or II sports at least twice a week
Exclusion Criteria:
- Current or previous injury to the contralateral leg
- Another grade III ligament injury, fracture, full-thickness articular cartilage damage

overall_official.affiliation: Norwegian Research Center for Active Rehabilitation
